speaker: Ron Paul
vclaim: "We've lost over 5,000 Americans over there in Afghanistan, in Iraq, and plus the civilians killed."
date: stated on September 5, 2007 in a debate in Durham, N.H.:
title: Fatality count isn't that high
text:
Paul's numbers are off, but not by a lot.

According to the Defense Department, 3,741 American troops had been killed in Iraq as of Sept. 5, 2007. The corresponding figure for deaths in Afghanistan is 372.


In addition, 232 American civilian workers have been killed in Iraq, according to the latest report of the Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction.


Featured Fact-check
















Charlie Kirk


stated on January 26, 2021 in an Instagram post








"Joe Biden admits he is governing like a 'dictator.'"












By Daniel Funke • January 28, 2021








Official figures are difficult to come by for civilian deaths in Afghanistan, but the Web site icasualties.org, which tracks casualties in Iraq and Afghanistan, lists only four American civilian deaths in Afghanistan.


So, add up the military deaths, combined with the American civilian casualties from the SIGIR report and icasualties.org, and it totals 4,349. This figure is significant, but short of Congressman Paul's assertion of over 5,000.
